metadata.name: Assessment Methods
metadata.description: Approaches to evaluating learning progress, understanding, and competence. Covers formative assessment, summative assessment, diagnostic assessment, authentic assessment, self-assessment, peer assessment, portfolio assessment, and rubric-based assessment.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Approaches to evaluating learning progress, understanding, and competence

positive_examples: We use formative assessment throughout the unit to track progress.
The portfolio demonstrates growth over the semester.
Exit tickets give me quick feedback on today's learning.
The rubric makes expectations transparent and grading consistent.
negative_examples: The lesson covered photosynthesis.
Students worked in groups.
The projector displayed the slides.
training_hints.disambiguation: Methods for evaluating learning, not teaching methods

candidates.definition: Ongoing assessment during learning to monitor progress and adjust instruction in real-time

positive_examples: Quick check: thumbs up if you understand, thumbs down if you need more help.
The exit ticket showed most students were confused about step 3.
Based on their responses, I adjusted tomorrow's lesson.
Continuous feedback loops that inform instruction as learning happens.
negative_examples: The final exam will count for 50% of your grade.
You'll find out how you did when report cards come out.
The standardized test happens at the end of the year.
training_hints.disambiguation: Ongoing assessment to guide instruction, not final evaluation

candidates.definition: Evaluation at the end of a learning period to measure achievement against standards

positive_examples: The final exam covers everything from the entire semester.
Your grade on this project determines whether you pass the course.
The end-of-unit test measures mastery of the learning objectives.
Standardized tests provide summative data on student achievement.
negative_examples: Let me see how you're doing so far - don't worry, this doesn't count.
Quick quiz to see if we need to review before moving on.
Show me your thinking process, not just the final answer.

candidates.definition: Assessment before instruction to identify prior knowledge, skills, and misconceptions

positive_examples: Before starting the unit, let's see what you already know.
The diagnostic revealed common misconceptions about fractions.
Pre-test results help me tailor instruction to your needs.
Identifying knowledge gaps before teaching begins.
negative_examples: This counts toward your final grade.
The test covers material from this unit.
Let's see what you learned this semester.
training_hints.disambiguation: Assessment before instruction to diagnose needs

candidates.definition: Evaluation through real-world tasks that demonstrate meaningful application of learning

positive_examples: Students wrote letters to actual city officials about a real community issue.
The assessment asked them to design a solution for a genuine problem.
Present your findings to an audience of real scientists.
Tasks that mirror how knowledge is actually used in the real world.
negative_examples: Choose the best answer from A, B, C, or D.
Fill in the blank with the correct term.
Match the vocabulary words to their definitions.

candidates.definition: Learners evaluating their own work and progress to develop metacognitive skills

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Self-assessment develops learner autonomy and self-regulation

positive_examples: Rate your own understanding on a scale of 1-5.
Use the rubric to evaluate your essay before submitting.
What do you think you did well? What would you improve?
Reflecting on your own learning helps you become a more effective learner.
negative_examples: The teacher graded all the essays.
Your score is 85%.
See me after class for feedback on your paper.
training_hints.disambiguation: Learner evaluates own work, not teacher evaluation

candidates.definition: Learners evaluating each other's work, developing critical analysis and communication skills

positive_examples: Exchange papers with a partner and use the rubric to provide feedback.
Peer review helps you see your work through others' eyes.
Give specific, constructive feedback on two strengths and two areas for improvement.
Learning to evaluate others' work develops your own critical thinking.
negative_examples: Only the teacher will read your essay.
Your grade is based solely on my evaluation.
Keep your work to yourself.
training_hints.disambiguation: Peers evaluate each other, not just teacher evaluation

candidates.definition: Collection of work over time demonstrating growth, reflection, and achievement

positive_examples: Your portfolio should include your best work from each unit.
Include a reflection on how you've grown as a writer.
The portfolio shows your development over the entire year.
Select pieces that demonstrate your range of skills.
negative_examples: This one test determines your grade.
Turn in the assignment and forget about it.
Your work from last month doesn't matter anymore.
training_hints.disambiguation: Collection showing growth over time, not single-point tests

candidates.definition: Using explicit criteria and performance levels to provide consistent, transparent evaluation

positive_examples: The rubric shows exactly what distinguishes an A from a B.
Use the scoring guide to understand the expectations.
Each criterion is rated on a 4-point scale with clear descriptors.
The rubric ensures consistent grading across all students.
negative_examples: I'll know a good paper when I see it.
Grades are based on my overall impression.
The criteria are kept secret until after grading.
training_hints.disambiguation: Explicit criteria for evaluation, not impressionistic grading
